headline.main: Cancer Prevention Tied to Diet and Way of Life

docs.abstract: Study by Harvard School of Public Health finds that bad habits and unhealthy life styles cause 65 percent of cancer deaths; points to smoking, diet and lack of exercise; reports that only 2 percent of deaths are traced to environmental pollution and 10 percent to genetics; Dr Dimitrios Trichopoulos says public concern about environmental carcinogens is out of proportion to true risk (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Bad habits and an unhealthy way of life cause 65 percent of cancer deaths, a new study says. The Harvard School of Public Health study found that smoking, diet and lack of exercise caused a majority of deaths from cancer, while only 2 percent of deaths were traced to environmental pollution and 10 percent to genetics.

docs.abstract: Article on fattening of Americans, many of whom appear to have had their fill of fat-free foods; NPD Group survey finds nation is high on restaurant junk food, feasting on more french fries, hamburgers and chicken nuggets than last year; researcher Harry Balzer asks who is eating all those hamburgers, nearly six million more than last year, if Americans are as concerned about health and nutrition as they claim; survey relies on meal-by-meal diaries, mailed in daily to avoid revision by guilty parties; popular fantasy that low-fat cookies are healthful also noted (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: THE next time you hear about a friend's low-fat diet, the next time you see a kitchen stocked with low-fat cookbooks and fat-free snacks, consider this: Three of the fastest-growing foods in America are hamburgers, french fries and chicken nuggets. Several years after low-fat eating became a full-fledged national obsession, there are signs that many Americans may have had their fill of fatlessness.

docs.abstract: Richard Bernstein reviews book Eat Fat, by Richard Klein; Klein photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: EAT FAT By Richard Klein Illustrated. 247 pages. Pantheon. $24. Richard Klein, who ascended to the Contrarians' Hall of Fame with his book ''Cigarettes Are Sublime'' a couple of years ago, has done it again. Last time he wrote of the pleasures and the cultural importance of smoking. This time the subject is fat.
